questions.question: Sulfonamides are structural analogs of which of the following compounds?
Which of the following is not a topically used sulfonamide?

options.B: SulfasalazineSilver sulfadiazined) MafenideQuestion 3:Trimethoprim is an inhibitor of which of the following enzymes?a) Dihydropteroate synthaseb) Dihydrofolate reductase

questions.explanation: Sulfasalazine is a sulfonamide which is not used topically. It is used orally in the management ofulcerative colitis, rheumatoid arthritis, and regional enteritis.Sulfacetamide is used topically as eye drops for ophthalmic infections.Silver sulfadiazine and mafenide are used topically for the prevention of burn infections.

questions.question: Which of the following combinations is indicated for the prophylaxis of malaria?
questions.explanation: Sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine combination is used for prophylaxis and treatment of malaria causedby mefloquine-resistant strains of Plasmodium falciparum.Sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim is used in the treatment of Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia.Sulfadiazine-pyrimethamine is used in the treatment of toxoplasmosis.

questions.question: Which of the following options correctly describes the dose ratio of trimethoprim andsulfamethoxazole in co-trimoxazole?
questions.explanation: Co-trimoxazole is a combination of trimethoprim with sulfamethoxazole in the dose ratio of1:5 (trimethoprim sulfamethoxazole).The antimicrobial activity of this combination is because of its actions on sequential steps in thepathway of synthesis of tetrahydrofolic acid as shown in the image.Sulfonamides - Mechanism of actionDihyydropteroate diphosphate +para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA)SulfonamidesDihydropteratesynthetaseDihydropteroic acidGlutamateMARKOWDihydrofolic acidNADPHTrimethoprimeNADPDihydrofolatereductaseTetrahydrofolic acid(THFA)OMARROWEach agent alone usually exerts bacteriostatic activity. But when an organism is sensitive to bothagents, bactericidal activity may be achieved.Because trimethoprim is more lipid-soluble than sulfamethoxazole, it has a larger volume ofdistribution than the latter drug.Therefore, when 1 part of trimethoprim is given with 5 parts of sulfamethoxazole (dose ratio is 1:5;trimethoprim:sulfamethoxazole), the peak plasma concentrations are in the ratio of 1:20, which isoptimal for the combined effects of these drugs in vitro.

questions.question: Which of the following is the drug of choice for Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia prophylaxisin a patient who has undergone organ transplantation?
questions.explanation: 441Cotrimoxazole is considered the drug of choice for Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia prophylaxisin immunocompromised patients like patients who have undergone organ transplantation andHIV-positive patients.Other drugs that can be used for prophylaxis are:• Aerosolized pentamidine•• Dapsone• Dapsone plus pyrimethamine•Atovoquone

questions.question: Co-trimoxazole is not prescribed in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Chancroid was earlier treated with cotrimoxazole but it is not used anymore because betteralternatives like ceftriaxone, azithromycin, erythromycin, and ciprofloxacin exist.Options B & C: Cotrimoxazole is indicated in both upper and lower urinary tract infectionsand also in prostatitis.Option D: Patients with severe nocardiosis are initially treated with a combination includingcotrimoxazole, amikacin, and ceftriaxone or imipenem.

questions.question: An infant had a serum bilirubin level of 33 mg/dL. The mother might have taken which of thefollowing drugs during the third trimester for this to occur?
questions.explanation: Cotrimoxazole is a combination drug consisting of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole, of whichsulfamethoxazole is a sulfonamide. Sulphonamides displace bilirubin from plasma albumin,leading to elevation of serum bilirubin levels.These drugs can cross the placenta and are secreted in milk and can therefore cause kernicterusin newborn infants if they are given to pregnant women near term or during lactation.

questions.question: A girl presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain, dark-colored urine, andseizures. You find out that she was recently prescribed co-trimoxazole for a UTI. What is theprobable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given neurovisceral symptoms following the use of sulfonamides point towards a diagnosis ofacute intermittent porphyria (AIP).AIP is a rare heme biosynthesis disorder due to a partial deficiency of the enzymeporphobilinogen deaminase (PBGD). Diagnosis is made based on elevated urine PBG levels.Alcohol, infections, pregnancy, and certain medications can trigger attacks by inducing hemesynthesis. This results in the accumulation of porphyrin precursors, causing symptoms.Side effects of sulfonamides are:• Acute intermittent porphyria - sulphonamides precipitate attacks• Hypersensitivity reaction - urticaria, erythema nodosum, erythema multiforme of theStevens-Johnson type, exfoliative dermatitis, and photosensitivity442••Crystalluria - due to low solubility. It is treated with good hydration and alkalization of urineHemolysis in G-6-PD deficiency (sulphonamides are oxidizers)• Kernicterus in the newborn (displace bilirubin)

questions.question: What is the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones in gram-negative bacteria?
questions.explanation: Fluoroquinolones inhibit two essential type II topoisomerases, DNA gyrase (in gram-negativebacteria) and topoisomerase IV (in gram-positive bacteria).DNA gyrase introduces negative supercoils and thereby reduces the torsional strain that occurswhen double-stranded DNA is being unwound for replication or translation. Topoisomerases IV isresponsible for unlinking daughter chromosomes after replication. Quinolone antibiotics form acomplex with the topoisomerase enzyme and the DNA, and thereby block DNA replication andbacterial cell division.

questions.question: Which of the following fluoroquinolones has maximum bioavailability?
questions.explanation: Levofloxacin and ofloxacin have the maximum bioavailability among fluoroquinolones. Hence,intravenous and oral doses are the same for these drugs.

questions.question: A patient who is a known case of cystic fibrosis presents to the OPD with complaints of feverand increased cough with expectoration. Sputum culture is positive for Pseudomonasaeruginosa. Which of the following fluoroquinolones can be used in this condition?434
questions.explanation: Ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin have substantial activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and canbe used in this patient.Mild to moderate respiratory exacerbations owing to Pseudomonas aeruginosa in patients withcystic fibrosis respond to oral ciprofloxacin or levofloxacin therapy.Activity against streptococci is significantly greater with newer quinolones like levofloxacin,gemifloxacin, and moxifloxacin.Moxifloxacin has clinically significant activity against anaerobes including B. fragilis. It isreported to have similar efficacy to piperacillin-tazobactam for complicated intra-abdominalinfection.

questions.question: Which of the following quinolones is not approved for use in a patient diagnosed with urinarytract infection?
questions.explanation: Moxifloxacin does not accumulate significantly in urine and is not approved for the treatment ofurinary tract infections (UTIs).UTIS are the only indication for the use of nalidixic acid. Ciprofloxacin and norfloxacin can beused in UTIs caused by susceptible organisms.443

questions.question: A patient presents with a wound on his leg with purulent discharge. Pus culture was positivefor MRSA. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe?
questions.explanation: Delafloxacin is a newer fluoroquinolone approved for use in acute bacterial skin and skinstructural infections (ABSSSI) caused by susceptible bacteria including MRSA.Compared to other fluoroquinolones which are zwitterionic in nature, delafloxacin is anionic. Thisenables the molecule to achieve increased intracellular penetration and concentration, especiallyunder acidic conditions (skin wounds). This results in increased antimicrobial activity and adecreased adverse event profile at clinically potent doses.

questions.question: Which of the following fluoroquinolones can be used in a patient with rifampicin-resistantleprosy?
questions.explanation: Ofloxacin can be used in this patient as it is the fluoroquinolone that has high activity against M.leprae and is indicated in alternative multidrug therapy regimens for leprosy. It also has highactivity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.question: 435A patient presents to the OPD with sudden onset abdominal cramps, fever, and diarrhea. Heis a foreigner who is on a tour in India and is a known asthmatic on theophylline. You decideto start antibiotics. However, you would avoid ciprofloxacin in this patient because

options.C: Ciprofloxacin decreases the effect of theophylline

questions.explanation: Ciprofloxacin should not be given to this patient because it is a cytochrome P450 inhibitorand inhibits the metabolism of theophylline and can potentially lead to theophylline toxicity.Pefloxacin is another drug that inhibits the metabolism of theophylline and results in its toxicity.

questions.question: A 52-year-old man diagnosed with multi-drug resistant tuberculosis requires second-lineagents for his therapy. However, he is found to have a creatinine clearance of 50 ml/min.Which of the following fluoroquinolones can be started in this patient without dosageadjustment?
questions.explanation: Moxifloxacin is metabolized predominantly by the liver and hence can be used safely in patientswith decreased renal function without dose adjustment.Fluoroquinolones, especially moxifloxacin, may be used as part of multiple-drug regimens for thetreatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis.Most of the available fluoroquinolones are cleared predominantly by kidneys and dosage needs tobe adjusted in patients with renal failure. But fluoroquinolones such as moxifloxacinand pefloxacin undergo hepatic elimination and so should be used carefully in patients with liverdisease.

questions.question: A 65-year-old man presents with symptoms suggestive of Achilles tendon rupture. He hadundergone renal transplantation and is now being treated with an antimicrobial agent. Whichof the following antimicrobials might he be on?
questions.explanation: Among the following options, the most likely drug to have caused this condition isciprofloxacin, since Achilles tendon rupture and tendinitis are side effects of quinolones. Elderlypatients (>60 years), patients on corticosteroids and solid organ transplant recipients are at444higher risk.

questions.question: Which of the following is a urinary antiseptic?
questions.explanation: Methenamine is a urinary antiseptic and is indicated in urinary tract infections. At pH<5.5,methenamine releases formaldehyde that inhibits bacteria.Option A: Galantamine is a central anticholinesterase approved for the treatment of Alzheimer'sdisease.Option C: Mecamylamine is a ganglionic blocker that can be used as an antihypertensive agent.Option D: Pyrimethamine is an antimalarial agent.445

questions.question: Which of the following drugs would you prescribe to a patient in order to relieve pain due tourinary tract infection?
questions.explanation: Phenazopyridine can be prescribed to this patient since it is a urinary anesthetic. It is used as alocal anesthetic in urinary tract disorders to relieve the pain of lower urinary tract irritation, as incystitis, urethritis, or prostatitis.It does not have any antibacterial action but affords symptomatic relief of burning sensation,dysuria and urgency due to cystitis.

questions.question: A patient presents to the casualty with fever with chills and chest pain. He also gives historyof passing brown-colored urine. He was prescribed an antimicrobial drug for urinary tractinfection three days ago and his symptoms began after he had started this medication. Whichof the following antimicrobial agents had most likely been prescribed?
questions.explanation: The patient had most likely been prescribed nitrofurantoin as the scenario depicts side effects ofthis drug.Nitrofurantoin is a urinary antiseptic used against lower UTI caused by E.coli and enterococci. Itsuse results in brown urine. It is also associated with acute pneumonitis with fever, chills, cough,dyspnea, chest pain, pulmonary infiltration, and eosinophilia within hours to days of initiation oftherapy. The symptoms resolve quickly after discontinuation of the drug.The antibacterial activity of nitrofurantoin is due to its intracellular conversion to highly reactiveintermediates by bacterial reductases. These intermediates react nonspecifically with ribosomalproteins and disrupt the synthesis of proteins, RNA, DNA, and other metabolic processes.

questions.question: Which of the following fluoroquinolone is not given in liver disease?
questions.explanation: Pefloxacin is mainly metabolized in the liver and hence avoided in patients with liver disease.Quinolones with primarily hepatic metabolism include moxifloxacin, pefloxacin, and trovafloxacin(withdrawn from the market due to hepatotoxicity).Quinolones primarily excreted by the kidneys include ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, norfloxacin,lomefloxacin, and ofloxacin.446
